confession.seduction_context: Had been in trouble with salines at Einville for having unauthorized salt in houses, and was in despair because of great expenses he was incurring, and feeling that he would lose his case. Persin promised to help him and provide what he needed.

economic_context.details: Multiple witnesses owed money to Humbert or had financial disputes with him. Witness 4 (schoolmaster) owed him money and suspected him of causing death of oxen 'pour se paier et descharger son courage' (to pay himself and discharge his resentment). Witness 16 had dispute over tax charge, wanting accused to count day's labour against it. Humbert ran a cabaret and forge, indicating middling economic status. He spent 500-1000 francs over prior accusation and fines from salines officials.

hearsay_chains.source: Claude fille Nicolas Gardey of Parroie
hearsay_chains.content: Vosgien accused both Humbert and Mobille, Humbert hid Mobille for 5-6 weeks, asked him not to accuse him if taken, gave ecus to servant to prevent accusation, Mobille named all those accused by Jean except Humbert
2 years earlier Colas Dufour suspected him over sickness of horse after quarrel; threatened him, and it then recovered
he said she would pay more dearly than at the market
complain of his witchcraft, and threaten to have him tried
wife told him he should not quarrel with accused, and he would cause them some misfortune
heard he had made threats against them
heard his second wife Jehenne call him old witch while running away as he tried to beat her
heard him ask whether if he were a witch the priest and others would go and eat in his house

emotional_state_notes: appeared 'tout esperdu' (completely distraught) to Jean Tessainct during absence
said he could not withstand torture
instead of protesting when confronted with Jeannon femme Massel du Four, merely asked her if she was sure, then said he wanted to confess
described himself as 'homme colere et remuant, mais de peu de durée' (angry and restless man, but of little persistence)

third_parties.name: Persin (devil)
third_parties.context: seduced accused more than 5 years earlier, gave yellow powder and made wife ill

extraction_metadata.notes: Very detailed trial with 22 witnesses providing extensive testimony about reputation, quarrels, and animal deaths. Confession was made voluntarily after confrontation with another accused witch (Jeannon femme Massel du Four), then accused was placed on rack with minimal torture (1/3 turn only). Trial shows pattern of debt disputes and economic tensions. Accused had prior involvement with Jean Vosgien trial - tried to bribe officials and hid Didier Mobillé. Spent substantial sum (500-1000 francs) on prior legal troubles with salines officials. Economic status assessed as 'middling' based on: running cabaret and forge, ability to spend large sums on legal troubles, lending money to neighbors, having unauthorized salt. Uncertainty: Jean Petit Jean mentioned in confession (schoolmaster whose animals accused killed) may be same as witness 4 Jean Nicolas Niclas le jeune (also schoolmaster, age 28) - names slightly different but both schoolmasters who had financial disputes with accused. Confession included harming his own wife with powder for 6 years, making her bedridden on crutches. Trial proceeded very quickly: 13 days from first witness to death sentence approval.
